discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D + an L2 connection between C102 & 201 wouldn't be bad either.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.

//IMG//


An engineer is designing a hierarchical ISIS solution for an enterprise customer with these requirements:
• Users in areas 25 and 55 send and receive traffic from both backbone areas.
• Link flaps in areas 35 and 45 must not impact other areas.
• Routers will double within the next 12 months in areas 35 and 45.

Which design must the engineer select?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I agree with 08511d4, correct answer is B

Selected Answer: B
I think its B.

The default route should be towards the campus core (which presumably then connectes to other networks/internets). Summarisation should happen at the aggregation layer and its logical to present the core with a downstream summary. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Campus/routed-ex.html
"As a design tip, unless the overall network design dictates otherwise, it is highly recommended that the network be configured with a default route (0.0.0.0) that is sourced into the core of the network, either by a group of highly available sink holes routers or by Internet DMZ routers."

Selected Answer: C
I think it's C
A /17 summary could keep the two environments separated.

comments.content:
Not saying A, that looks wrong... 
B as suggested but should be summarized into /17's.

choices.B:
• The core layer must advertise a default route toward the aggregation layer.
• The VLAN subnets must be summarized into 10.0.0.0/16 at the aggregation layer and advertised to the core layer.
choices.D:
• The core layer must advertise a default route toward the aggregation layer.
• The VLAN subnets must be summarized into 10.0.0.0/16 at the access layer and advertised to the aggregation layer.
choices.C:
• The aggregation layer must advertise a default route toward the access layer.
• The VLAN subnets must be summarized into 10.0.0.0/16 at the aggregation layer and advertised to the core layer.
choices.A:
• The aggregation layer must advertise a default route toward the core layer.
• The VLAN subnets must be summarized into 10.0.0.0/16 at the aggregation layer and advertised to the access layer.

questions.question_text: What are two advantages of the Cisco SD-WAN technology? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I hate marketing question, because could also A - faster deployment when using ZTP and templates.

choices.C: communicates ENI and EVC attributes to the CE
choices.A: broadcasts multicast network routes from the CE to the PE
choices.D: broadcasts to all subnets from the CE when an EVC is added
choices.B: notifies the CE of the availability state of a configured EVC

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. notifies the CE of the availability state of a configured EVC.

The Ethernet LMI (Local Management Interface) protocol, as defined by the MEF 16 Technical Specification, is used in Carrier Ethernet networks to communicate the status and attributes of an Ethernet Virtual Connection (EVC). Specifically, LMI is used to notify the Customer Edge (CE) device about the availability state of an EVC, helping to ensure that the connection is active and operational between the CE and Provider Edge (PE) devices.

This process helps with network management by indicating when an EVC is established or if it goes down, and this notification ensures that the CE can take appropriate action.
it seems to me that both B and C answers are valid, both of them are procedures defined by MEF 16 TS
Seems way out of the scope of this exam

The Ethernet LMI protocol includes the following procedures, as defined by the MEF 16 Technical Specification:
• Notifying the CE when an EVC is added
• Notifying the CE when an EVC is deleted
• Notifying the CE of the availability state of a configured EVC (Active, Not Active, or Partially Active)
• Communicating UNI and EVC attributes to the CE
